review:
[u]NOTE: I haven't played in a while so this is based on my past experiences.[/u]

I've never seen the appeal of Battle Royale games and this was the first one I had ever played and it was just because my friends wanted me to.


I had a problem on day two of playing the game: after finishing a session the game wouldn't close itself, steam couldn't close it, Task Manager couldn't close it, powershell couldn't close it. I couldn't even shutdown or restart my PC. So I had to force a shutdown which, [i] somehow[/i], completely broke my Windows installation. So instead I installed it on Linux and played for a while, on and off for a couple of months. 
It isn't much fun to play solo so if your friends- like mine did- switch to a new game and if you're like me, you'll have little reason to play it.

[h2]The Good[/h2]

The gunplay is pretty good but some of the guns feel a bit meh. Like most games, the devs struggle to properly balance them, at least from my short experience and anecdotes from my friends.
The movement is fantastic, genuinely some of the most fun movement mechanics in any FPS I've ever played and yes, I [b] will[/b] eventually play Titanfall 2 before anyone points out it's basically/exactly the same.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]

The Monetization of the game is disgusting, it was probably the most expensive mainstream game for cosmetics at the time, especially for the high tier stuff, iirc and I could be wrong with this analogy, to get the best of the best stuff it would be like if you had to own every Pokemon card released in a series before you were even permitted to PAY for the most expensive card. 
It used to be that you could pay for the first battlepass and as long as you played the entirety or majority of the battlepass you'd have earned enough premium currency to pay for the next but according to people I know whom still play (and the tons of videos people made complaining about this change when it happened), that is no longer the case.
If you do still play it, don't give them any money. If they stop getting money, things get cheaper, then you can consider buying something if you want to. Meaningless cosmetics only keep getting more and more expensive is because people still pay for them, if everyone voted with their wallet, they would be forced to lower the price.

[h2]The Inconsequential[/h2]

Long after I stopped playing the game they made the decision to disable access to Linux players and since I am certainly never going to play this on Windows because it broke my previous installation, now I can't even play it on Linux if I wanted to (also W10 is dead and W11 is trash, so that doesn't help). They blocked Linux users because, according to developers a "significant amount of cheaters were using Linux" (Not verbatim). Which sucks for legitimate players but oh well. I do not know if the game has improved after these changes or not, ask someone who still plays. I had already quit a long time ago so I didn't care too much, though I did have two achievements left to get which sucks.


[h2] The tl;dr [/h2]avoid, there are better games around, maybe check it out if you start seeing a plethora of new people talking about 'how good it is now' if that ever happens. Not bad for my first and only experience of a battle royale game but poorly handled, definitely hasn't made me want to play any other Battle Royale games as I actually much preferred the Arena mode.
name: Apex Legends‚Ñ¢

review:
Apex Legends is an absolute gem of a battle royale game that has kept me hooked for over 1,000 hours. The fast paced gameplay, slick movement mechanics, and diverse roster of Legends make every match feel fresh and exhilarating. The gunplay is crisp, rewarding skill and strategy, while the ping system and team focused design make it a blast to play with friends or even random squads.

My favorite Legend, Valkyrie, is a game changer. Her jetpack mobility lets you soar above the chaos, reposition with ease, and scout enemy squads like a pro. Her tactical and ultimate abilities add such a dynamic layer to gameplay, whether you're raining missiles or launching your team to a new vantage point. She perfectly embodies the high-flying, aggressive playstyle I love.

The constant updates, vibrant maps, and evolving meta keep Apex feeling alive and engaging. Whether you're a casual player or a sweaty tryhard like me, Apex Legends delivers endless thrills and moments of pure adrenaline. Highly recommend diving in!

review:
I don't like leaving reviews for games but sadly it has come to this.

I came from console, Day 1 player and enjoyed everything the game offered. The gameplay, the gunplay (absolutely superior), and how the characters worked really made this game stand out against other BR games. (Fortnite, PUBG, etc.)
And for a long time this game was great. It did EVERYTHING right. But something happened and now this game is the least amount of fun I have ever had with this genre. 

Identity wise? This game is a former shell of what it used to be. It no longer screams "Respawn Entertainment" and shoves "We will pretend to be them so YOU won't notice." If you are a casual player - and what I mean is if you like playing this game with friends having a good time and just win or lose? this game will never be for YOU anymore. Since every game seems to only cater to the less than 1% of gamers (The real Esports players) you will hate it. 

This game used to be about dropping in, whether it was Hot drops or far away and still being able to have fun. Now regardless of what mode (Ranked or Unranked) every match is sitting and waiting. or "Ratting": for those who care about the actual name for it. Its no longer fast paced fun, its Walking and sitting simulator where you get to hear characters talk among themselves until you either 5th party or ultimately die.

Do not get this review wrong! I enjoyed playing ranked, I enjoyed the other modes and new characters they have added. But if the character isn't meta? You might as well just sit in the menu and listen to the music. Cause that is exactly where you will be 90% of the time. 

EA and Respawns "Relationship" with this game is a cancer and for whatever reason... they don't want to give it the proper love it TRULY needs. Its money hungry, as all hell. Split battlepasses? who tf even thinks of something stupid like this? this game has more character skins and new thousand $ heirloom items than quality of life changes. Sadly in typical EA fashion they will never bring this game back to its former glory. Its cheating or nothing with the player-base and its the most unfun I have ever had from being a day one player.

You would have more fun playing an old EA game from the early 2000's than this. If I could refund everything, I would. Please save your sanity, controller,mouse and hell even your monitor the trouble of being broken.
name: Apex Legends‚Ñ¢

review:
Game mechanics sucks, but lore and story-wis,e is great. I like the characters and map design. What I can't get with is the gun mechanics. I've played video games for over 20 years, from Call of Duty and Battlefield to other lesser-known games, such as Counter-Strike. I am really not a fun of slow movement, slow bullet speed. I know many says this game is fast-paced and so on but it is just an illusion. The effects and FOV make you think that but play COD or even bf. There are faster engagements where timing and quick reactions are more important. Now, you might say this makes decision-making better in Apex but not really. If you throw a lot of factors and want to hide different low skills and hope for an RNG win from one or multiple factors, then it is easier. If you know your gun, movements and recoil pattern, then you shall not be RNG into a win/lose situation. I am more into pure physical-based games than software as a limiting factor. What I mean is I prefer my physical body to be the limiting factor and not the game. 

I suck at this game the most from all the FPS shooters and is because of it's software limitations. I can calculate bullet drops, ballistics, different patterns of movements and rotation but here is a RNG fest where your pure skills are limited by RNG and random items. I believe they should help you but not handicap your inner skill.

review:
Hah, another FPS, another day.
Its taken only 15 hours for me to get sick of the moronic matchmaking in this game. This is not fun for a solo quewe, and not fun for a noob. The core gameplay is ok, but theres a lot of different tokens, passes, items, upgrades etc etc to learn and can be overwhelming.

The cheating is a little less obvious on this game, but its there, especially with abundant smurfs. I enjoyed the gunplay at range, but up close its worse than COD for having players flying around you like farts in the wind.

In the end my stats showed it will give me maybe 1 in 25 games a fair shot, and the rest of the time im dead so fast its no fun at all. Ive never had such a low K/D in any FPS i played in over 25 years, this is because of the unfair lobbies i find myself in every game. 0.5 K/D is me being whooping boy, most other FPS im over 1 KD.

Save yourself the trouble, pass on this unless you fancy a hundred hours of learning whilst getting blazed in most games you play by most players you meet.

review:
In short, I don't recommend this game to any newbies or even people who went away from the game for a while and want to re-visit. PLEASE just don't.

After nearly 5000 hrs across Origin and Steam, I've been through every meta, the highs and the lows, grinding for Pred, tried comp (not good enough to make it tho lol), and was a fan of prime TSM. The state of the game for the past couple of years has been terrible. There were good changes and a lot of bad changes.

TTK
The first thing that I want to address is the current TTK. You might say that I don't adapt to the meta or whatever, but it's not healthy for the game at all, imo. You can peek and die in a second without any way to fight back. It's lowering the skill ceiling and overall NOT fun at all. 
(I still remember, back in 2021, one-clipping people with MNK was really hard and super rewarding but now any one can do that because meta guns can shoot 200 damage in 1-2 sec or 2 shots.)

Free movement??
Movement, oh movement, this is what made me fall in love with this game. Spending hundreds of hours perfecting all the movement tech - wallbounce, super jump, superglide, mantle jump, tap-strafing, Faide slide, etc. etc. (Ik many of them are gimmicky but when you can pull them off to outplay enemies, it makes my brain go monkey mode). Then Apex introduced Ash's dash and Sparrow's jump where with a click of a button, you get free movement with no effort. These abilities make me not want to grind the tech anymore and slowly lose interest in the game.

POOR AUDIO
FFS, the devs mentioned fixing the no-audio bug so many times, but why on earth, in late 2025, do we still get this bug over and over again? You can't even hear the whole team running next to you (check out Monsoon's tweet, the whole team was running and shooting at him with 0 audio in ALGS). Welp, they actually made the footsteps of teammates louder than opponents.

SOLO? Do not play ranked.
We are 26 seasons in, but the devs never mentioned about solo or solo/duo queue lobbies in ranked. Don't they know how unhealthy it is for the game? At least add the option for people to turn it on/off. 
Anyways, I think solo can be enjoyable in low ranks (bronze to plat), but after diamond you will see a significant amount of boosters (low-level, low kill counts, boosting people to Masters), 3 stacking Preds/ex-Preds or Masters running around destroying you. I know some people are good enough to do this challenge, but I'd say it's not enjoyable by any means considering we rarely get comms in this game, at least in the ASIA server.

I might visit the game every now and then to play with friends, but as of right now...
GG Legends.
name: Apex Legends‚Ñ¢

review: **Apex Legends** has arguably the best core gunplay and movement mechanics in the entire battle royale market, offering a fast, fluid, and genuinely high-skill ceiling experience. However, that stellar foundation is constantly sabotaged by years of frustrating, often opaque matchmaking decisions that prioritize queue times over fair play. The "hero shooter" element feels diluted, serving more as a veneer for a game that excels at making solo players feel utterly helpless against coordinated three-stacks. While the ongoing content cycle keeps the game feeling fresh, it also suffers from persistent technical issues, most notably inconsistent audio cues, which remain unforgivable for a top-tier competitive title.

review:
421 hours later, and I‚Äôve realized Apex isn‚Äôt just a shooter ‚Äî it‚Äôs a trust exercise gone wrong. You drop in with randoms who either laser entire squads solo or sprint into a 1v3 with a Mozambique yelling ‚Äúfollow me!‚Äù.

The gunplay? Absolutely top-tier. Movement? Smooth as butter on ice. Every legend feels unique, and mastering their abilities gives real satisfaction. But man, the third-party fights and matchmaking can sometimes make you want to uninstall mid-air.

When the flow clicks though ‚Äî you slide, beam, and clutch a 1v3 with red armor ‚Äî it‚Äôs pure adrenaline. That high keeps you coming back.

üéÆ Pros:

God-tier gunplay and movement mechanics

Unique legends with diverse playstyles

Frequent events and cosmetics (if you can afford them)

Crossplay that actually works

üíÄ Cons:
‚Äì Matchmaking sometimes throws you against full sweats while you‚Äôre solo queueing with two loot goblins
‚Äì Server lag and occasional bugs still haunt the game
‚Äì Expensive skins and battle passes
‚Äì Third parties. So. Many. Third. Parties.

‚öñÔ∏è Verdict:
It‚Äôs frustrating, exhilarating, and addictive all at once. Apex doesn‚Äôt respect your time, but it sure rewards your skill.
Thumbs Up üëç (421 hrs of sliding, dying, and somehow coming back for more)

review:
Apex is an Unhealthy Game.

Now before you jump in my throat not knowing what I mean by this, hear me out here, also TLDR is at the bottom.

Apex is such a great game, best BR currently in the gaming world with no competition yet in sight, a lot of people quit playing other games and focused solely on apex and for me it‚Äôs one of my fav games and I spent a lot of time on this game since day 1.

But as a lot of you are witnessing as the seasons are going by, apex has become more of a stress game than a fun/chill one, which is due to obvious reasons that I won‚Äôt dive into since it has no solution for it in sight and I think it will only get worse from here on end but that stress in itself took a hard toll on a lot of the players behaviors, mental health and some physical health.

Most people who play apex don‚Äôt just play for an hour or two, they grind away for hours whether its ranked or to get higher levels/kills in pubs or whatever they are trying to achieve in the game. The gameplay mechanics is certainly addictive based more than any fps game that I played before and can keep you hooked for a long time with match after match like a drug.

Apex has become a stress filled game and that constant stress had started to show on people and players especially on pro/streamer players who spend a lot of time on this game, a lot of them tweet from time to time that they need a break from apex or they will get actually physically sick. Watch a tournament if you haven‚Äôt already and see for yourself how each team are screaming loudly in anxiety voice, panics and complete stress with each move. Granted it‚Äôs a tournament and money is on the line but again I‚Äôve seen this quite strongly in apex more than any other game.

I had friends who quit the game even though they like it but because it has become so stressful for them to play. The constant anxiety and stress of playing and trying to survive or clutch over and over for hours in lots of matches for example is not something that passes by peacefully on the body and mental health for every person no matter how much you love its adrenaline rush. It‚Äôs extremely draining and can be quite harmful on the long run.

The accumulation of this stress for long hours a day, and months on end will show in the form of mental exhaustion and can lead to actual physical health problems. Now you will probably say well its like that with any fps game if it is ‚Äúover-played‚Äù and while that is true, apex is more profound and way faster to show these side effects more than any other game that I have played before.

For me personally, no matter how much of a break I took from the game, weeks or months on end. After coming back to the game and the stress wheel of gameplay starts to get back in motion from grinding away in the game, it was one of the factors (Along with usual life stresses) that got my anxiety problems back, constant tension and even lead to IBS and other stomach problems and I‚Äôm back on medications and I‚Äôm only starting to show a bit of improvement after I put the game on a long hold. If your life is already stressful, apex can definitely be like adding fuel to the fire and can hasten health issues.

A friend of mine had to quit the game after he started having heart stress related issues when he used to grind the game for hours and days on end trying to rank up. And after he quit, he became much better health wise.

Of course not all people experience that and each person body respond differently to stress than the other person and some even managed to play this game calmly or have nerves of steel but again it‚Äôs not for everyone to be able to do that. For apex is more stressful than any other game I have ever played before and I‚Äôm sure a lot of people will agree with me on this. Heck i can play titanfall 2 for example with its crazy speed and not have half the anxiety and stress I get in apex.

Aside from broken Sbmm, broken servers and frustrations of gameplay. other reasons in the game and one of the things I noticed and I could be wrong but the people I know who played the game agreed with me on this is that the sounds of the game itself can be very stressful.

Something in the weapon sharp firing sounds, running footsteps of some of the legends ‚Äúwhen they are actually heard lol‚Äù (for example octane‚Äôs squeaky fast robotic legs, or Bangalore‚Äôs rapid running footsteps when you are getting pushed by one, some of the weapons and shooting shields sounds can be a bit nerve wracking especially in fast paced end-game scenarios. And since you are also not hearing it just from one team in an area but multiple teams on end one after the other in every match you play as you are trying to survive and score a win.

In general what I‚Äôm trying to say here is that be careful and put your health first before apex or any game stress and anxiety filled like that, I‚Äôm speaking from an actual experience of mine and others. take lots of breaks in between and minimize your play time so you won‚Äôt regret it if an actual health related issue started to show, cause constant stress from a video game or anything else can lead to serious health problems and these problems can sneak up on you no matter how much you feel that you are fine while playing it and in control.

TLDR : Apex can be a very stressful and nerve wracking game and it‚Äôs constant stress can cause some serious health issues. Put your health first before it no matter how much you love the game.

review:
Apex Legends is the kind of game that makes you want to scream into your headset, uninstall it in a fit of rage, and then reinstall it five minutes later because you remembered how good it used to be. It‚Äôs a battle royale that promised innovation, polish, and excitement ‚Äî and while it occasionally delivers, it often feels like Respawn is juggling chainsaws blindfolded.
If you‚Äôre new to Apex Legends, prepare to be obliterated. The game throws you into matches with players who have thousands of hours under their belts, and unless you‚Äôre a Twitch-tier FPS god, you‚Äôll spend your first dozen games as a glorified loot mule. The movement system ‚Äî while fluid and exhilarating ‚Äî is also punishingly complex. Slide-jumping, wall-bouncing, tap-strafing‚Ä¶ these aren‚Äôt just advanced techniques; they‚Äôre practically required if you want to survive past the first ring.
There‚Äôs no meaningful onboarding. The firing range is a joke compared to what other shooters offer. Want to practice against bots? Too bad. Want to learn how to rotate properly or use cover effectively? Figure it out yourself. Apex assumes you‚Äôre either already good or willing to suffer until you are.
Skill-based matchmaking (SBMM) in Apex Legends is like trying to balance a seesaw with a bowling ball and a feather. One match you‚Äôre up against casuals who barely know how to reload, and the next you‚Äôre facing a full-stack Predator squad that wipes you before you can say ‚ÄúMozambique here.‚Äù Ranked mode is supposed to fix this, but it‚Äôs a mess of its own. The point system rewards camping and ratting more than actual combat, and the matchmaking often throws wildly different skill levels into the same lobby.
And don‚Äôt get me started on solo queueing. If you‚Äôre not playing with friends, expect teammates who drop solo, disconnect mid-match, or loot your death box while you‚Äôre still bleeding out. Communication is key in Apex, but the game punishes you for trusting randoms.
Every season brings a new legend, a new weapon tweak, and a new set of balance issues. Some legends are laughably overpowered (hello, Seer Season 10), while others are so underwhelming they might as well be cosmetic skins. The devs seem to swing wildly between buffing and nerfing without a clear vision of what the meta should be.
Weapons follow the same chaotic pattern. One season the R-99 is a laser beam, the next it‚Äôs a pea shooter. The Volt gets vaulted, then unvaulted, then nerfed. Shotguns go from reliable to useless in a single patch. It‚Äôs exhausting trying to keep up, and it often feels like Respawn is testing changes on live servers rather than doing internal QA.
For a game that‚Äôs been out since 2019, Apex Legends still feels like it‚Äôs held together with duct tape and hope. Server disconnects are common, especially during peak hours. Audio bugs ‚Äî like silent footsteps or gunfire that sounds like it‚Äôs coming from another dimension ‚Äî can cost you entire matches. Hit registration is inconsistent, and sometimes it feels like bullets just vanish into thin air.
There are also bizarre visual glitches, like textures not loading or legends T-posing mid-match. And let‚Äôs not forget the infamous ‚Äúcode: net‚Äù errors that boot you out of games for no reason. Respawn‚Äôs response to these issues is usually slow, vague, or nonexistent.
Apex Legends is free-to-play, but it‚Äôs aggressively monetized. The battle pass is underwhelming, filled with filler items and grindy challenges. Cosmetics are overpriced ‚Äî $20 for a skin that looks like a recolor of last season‚Äôs? Really? And the heirloom system is borderline predatory. You either spend hundreds of dollars during a limited-time event or hope to get lucky after opening 500 loot boxes.
Even the store layout feels manipulative, with rotating bundles and FOMO-driven sales. Respawn knows players want cool cosmetics, and they‚Äôve built a system that milks that desire for all it‚Äôs worth.
The world of Apex Legends has so much potential. The characters are rich with backstories, the setting is tied to the Titanfall universe, and the seasonal comics hint at deeper conflicts. But the game rarely capitalizes on this. Lore is drip-fed through short videos or loading screen blurbs, and most players ignore it entirely.
There‚Äôs no campaign, no meaningful single-player content, and no way to explore the world outside of matches. Legends have voice lines that tease relationships and rivalries, but they‚Äôre never developed. It‚Äôs like Respawn built a beautiful sandbox and forgot to put any toys in it.
For a game that‚Äôs been around for years, Apex Legends has surprisingly few permanent modes. Control and Gun Run are fun, but they‚Äôre rotated in and out like seasonal decorations. There‚Äôs no consistent alternative to battle royale, and that‚Äôs a shame ‚Äî because not everyone wants to spend 20 minutes looting only to die in 10 seconds.
Map rotation is another sore spot. Some maps are clearly better than others (Olympus is a fan favorite, Storm Point is divisive), but players don‚Äôt get to choose. You‚Äôre stuck with whatever Respawn decides, and that often means enduring weeks of a map you hate.
The Apex Legends community can be brutal. Teammates rage-quit, flame you in chat, or spam pings like it‚Äôs Morse code. Ranked grind leads to burnout, and casual matches are often filled with smurfs or people just trying to complete battle pass challenges. There‚Äôs little incentive to play for fun, and the competitive pressure can suck the joy out of the experience.
Respawn has made some efforts to curb toxicity ‚Äî like muting pings or reporting players ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not enough. The game needs better systems for rewarding teamwork and discouraging griefing.
Despite all of this ‚Äî the bugs, the balance issues, the matchmaking chaos, the monetization ‚Äî Apex Legends still has something special. The movement is unmatched. The gunplay is crisp. The legends are memorable. When everything clicks ‚Äî when your squad is coordinated, your shots land, and you clutch a win ‚Äî it feels incredible.
It‚Äôs flawed, frustrating, and often infuriating. But it‚Äôs also thrilling, rewarding, and unlike anything else out there.
So yeah‚Ä¶ I hate it.
But I love it too.

review:
After a long time playing (2200h xbox / 70h pc) since season 2, I still enjoy dropping in from time to time. 

+ The weapons, combat, movement, skills and characters make this game so fun, with a lot of possibilities!

- There is a dilemma with which mode to play as a solo player: ranked or unranked. Unranked can be fun but generally will be one epic team and a bunch of fodder. 9/10, your team mates have no intention of winning so they leave while knocked which is very frustrating.
Ranked eliminates this problem and people see genuinely motivated to survive at all costs. However, you won't often get an amazingly successful game when you're at your skill limit and it becomes a very frustrating points grind. Particularly when your team will often have some lunatic willing to sprint to Valhalla.

I mostly play with voice chat off which doesn't help this tactical game at all! The amount of insanely angry people who will get killed on their own and then shout at you constantly while you're trying to rescue them (to often die yourself) is just crazy! 

These are hard problems to fix and probably exist in most similar games.

For a good experience, play with friends.
name: Apex Legends‚Ñ¢

review:
The love-hate relationship continues...

After 1200+ hours, I can say PUBG is one of the most thrilling and realistic battle royale games out there. The gunplay, recoil, and overall tension in every match are unmatched ‚Äî when it works, it‚Äôs pure adrenaline.

But the biggest problem remains the cheaters. They still pop up too often, and most only get short bans (sometimes just 24 hours). It‚Äôs frustrating to see such a great game dragged down by weak enforcement.

Still, despite the issues, I keep coming back. Because when PUBG shines - nothing else comes close.

review:
PUBG is the game that launched a thousand "just one more match" lies to yourself at 2 AM. Across various platforms. 
The gunplay is chef's kiss - legitimately satisfying in a way that makes you feel like a tactical genius when you win a fight, and a complete potato when you don't. The bullet physics actually matter here. Leading shots, accounting for drop, calculating‚Äî okay fine, I'm just spraying and praying, but it FEELS tactical.
TL;DR: Clunky, brutal, addictive. Although as in any game, its better with friends. Randoms and the community here is not too friendly or more accurate than your grandpa.

review:
The game is still fun to play, but it‚Äôs gained a dose of ‚Äúflashiness‚Äù ‚Äî with loads of clothing options, weapon skins, helmets, and similar extras ‚Äî making it look more like a free-to-play title from some Korean studio that‚Äôs focused on farming money through pay-to-win mechanics. In this case, though, it‚Äôs more of a ‚Äúpay-to-look‚Äù situation, if that term even exists.

In any case, PUBG can still be enjoyable, but the overloaded menus and abundance of cosmetic items have, in a way, dragged the game down a bit. The core mechanics, however, remain recognizable ‚Äî the very thing that has kept the game alive for the past 12 or 13 years. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs not what it used to be at its peak, but there‚Äôs still a solid player base.

I hope the old battle passes make a return, along with the removal of all the unnecessary colorfulness that‚Äôs crept into the menus and main screen, and that the map selection system comes back. I believe those changes could bring back a good number of players as well.

For what you've done to other people's nerves, you don't even deserve to wake up and see the light of day. If hell exists, it's for YOU. So many thousands of people experienced this game's greatness, yet it remains the only place to play with old friends. These people are hostage to good memories created by some and ruined by other, disgusting people. If you're a developer reading this review (not just some newbie, but the one responsible for the mindless updates that are killing the game), know that there are hundreds of thousands of people in this world who wish you ill, and you deserve it.
No, I didn't play this game for 200-300 hours and dislike it. I spent 3,500 hours in it and know what it was and should be like. I have every right to consider you talentless parodies of people and hope that karma catches up with you.

review: I bought this game 2 times. First time when it came out on Xbox one. Pretty terrible port. Then 4 years later I bought it on PC for a proper way to play and it runs very inconsistently albeit fine. Its now free and I find myself coming back here and there. Should've been free to begin with IMO if you played the console port. I would recommend only because this is one of the first battle royale games and you can see where the idea came from and its actually a great game when there isnt a cheater in your lobby.
name: PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS

review: A few months ago the devs updated the AI/bots. Since then, people are continuing to stop playing this game at an alarming rate. People I have played with for years have all found new games to play. The devs should be able to see this with their own data. I have also been reading that the company that owns pubg wants to become an "AI first" company. Great. Keep going. You will end up with random noobs who only stay for a game or two. The game is constantly leaning toward larger maps where you constantly have to drive and drive. Combining different locations in one server and prioritizing vehicles creates an incredible amount of lag. The quest to improve the game is actually doing the opposite. Players leaving in droves, never to return while the devs continue to manipulate the players. I have since the game started and sadly, will not be continuing to play this garbage anymore. Maybe the devs can have ai play ai while they have a circle jerk about what an amazing product they think they have created.

review:
Yes, I would tentatively recommend PUBG: Battlegrounds on PC, especially since it is now a free-to-play game.

Tentatively means I suggest it, but with some important things you should know first.

Yes, tentatively I recommend it. It is one of the most popular and original Battle Royale games, offering a unique, tense, and realistic shooter experience.

No, I cannot fully recommend it without mentioning the steep learning curve and the high system requirements for a smooth experience, and the issue of cheating in the community.

review:
PUBG ‚Äî Overrated and Overpriced Chaos

PUBG has always felt like an overrated game to me. For something with such high system requirements, it‚Äôs surprising how dated it actually looks ‚Äî I‚Äôve seen games from 2007 with better graphics and smoother performance.

Gameplay-wise, it‚Äôs mostly running, looting, and then getting randomly shot out of nowhere. There‚Äôs rarely a real sense of skill or satisfaction ‚Äî just frustration. It can be fun with friends, sure, but on your own, it quickly becomes repetitive and empty.

Upgrading to Premium was a mistake ‚Äî total waste of money. And the cosmetics? Feels like they were made for anime fans rather than for a gritty battle royale.

PUBG had potential, but it‚Äôs hard to enjoy when everything about it feels clunky, unbalanced, and focused more on microtransactions than fun.
name: PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS

I would like to say i recommend this game but it is good up until a point.

if you just play sometimes for fun and spend no money on it then you might enjoy the time you give to it but as a player that plays this game almost daily i am kinda fed up with the map select mode which is random and it is random from the same 3 maps every day and it gets old at this point. No new maps, no option to not run into the same map every day for weeks or months.

If the devs find a way to fix this issue maybe i will change my review but the game at this point is not really a long term type of game since you play the same map every day, probably the last time i have seen Sanhok was last year, since then i have never seen it, i only run into Erangel, Miramar And sometimes Deston but that's pretty much it.

Horrible design.

review:
I‚Äôve never played a game that manages to be this consistently awful and somehow proud of it. The gunplay feels like aiming with a shopping cart on ice. The vehicles handle like drunk cows on roller skates. Every building looks like it was designed by someone who hates textures. Half the matches are spent running through empty fields praying you don‚Äôt get sniped by some dude camping in a bush since 2018.

The servers lag like they‚Äôre powered by a hamster on its last leg, and the sound design? Don‚Äôt get me started. Footsteps sound like they‚Äôre coming from every direction except the one the enemy‚Äôs actually in. And yet‚Ä¶ somehow‚Ä¶ I keep playing.

10/10. Would recommend.

review:
I started playing when it released for a year or so.  Returned 2 years ago to find loot everywhere, ability to hot drop to decent gear, and not end up in phase 4 with a shotgun. The improvements since release, up to current, constant new content, constant new updates, cosmetics, just show why this game has lasted as long as it has.
Still in my opinion the best, most pure BR experience you can have.
Nothing more satisfying than mastering the AUG recoil and spraying at 100m or the unforgettable bolt rifle headshot from 500+.
I don't think the sound of firing any sniper in the game will ever leave my mind - especially the Kar98k.

To compensate for these god forsaken decisions, they decided to implement skibidi toilet as an event into the game, which you can participate in for literally no reason or benefit, and there's also an option to pay them a monthly subscription to get absolutely nothing in return, except for cheesy and ugly skins and clothes to equip your character in this absolutely dead game.

Dog sh*t.

review:
PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS remains one of the most iconic titles in the battle royale genre, offering a gritty, realistic survival experience that keeps your heart racing from the first drop to the final circle. The gunplay feels weighty and authentic, the map design encourages smart tactics, and every match tells its own intense story of survival and strategy.

Since going free-to-play, PUBG has become more accessible than ever, bringing in a wave of new players and keeping the action lively. However, this shift has also caused some issues ‚Äî items and cosmetics that were once paid or exclusive have occasionally become free, frustrating long-time players who invested early.

Even with that hiccup, PUBG continues to deliver tense, memorable gameplay and remains a must-play for fans of competitive shooters.

Verdict: A battle royale classic that still delivers ‚Äî just wish the item system respected veteran players a bit more. ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚òÜ

review:
This one feels like saying goodbye to an old friend. PUBG was one of the first big battle royales that actually felt intense and rewarding ‚Äî it set the tone for a whole genre. These days though, it‚Äôs definitely showing its age. The graphics are mediocre (even for its time, honestly), and while the gameplay is still fun at its core, the clunkiness is really hard to ignore now.

Quick Ratings:
‚Ä¢ Graphics: 3/5
‚Ä¢ Gameplay: 3.5/5
‚Ä¢ Sound: 3/5
‚Ä¢ Immersion: 4/5
‚Ä¢ Fun Factor: 4/5
‚Ä¢ Value: 5/5
‚Ä¢ Overall: 3.5/5

When it first came out, PUBG was groundbreaking ‚Äî nerve-wracking, chaotic, and full of those ‚Äújust one more round‚Äù moments. The tension of hearing footsteps closing in, the scramble for loot, the satisfaction of getting that chicken dinner ‚Äî it all worked. But time hasn‚Äôt been kind to it. The gunplay feels stiff and awkward now, the optimization is still poor after all these years, and the ranked scene in the U.S. is basically dead.

It‚Äôs free now, and that helps, but even then, it feels like they‚Äôre hanging on by a thread. The seasonal content doesn‚Äôt add much, and the small rewards don‚Äôt make up for how stale it‚Äôs become. It‚Äôs not that the game is bad ‚Äî it‚Äôs just been passed by. With newer titles like the latest Battlefield and other modern shooters redefining what large-scale multiplayer can look like, PUBG feels like it‚Äôs finally run its course.

Pros:
‚Ä¢ Classic and foundational to the battle royale genre
‚Ä¢ Still fun with friends, especially in casual matches
‚Ä¢ Free to play with some small rewards
‚Ä¢ Good sense of tension and immersion

Cons:
‚Ä¢ Dated graphics and clunky mechanics
‚Ä¢ Terrible optimization after all these years
‚Ä¢ Ranked mode is almost unplayable in North America
‚Ä¢ Seasonal content is repetitive and low value
‚Ä¢ Feels outdated compared to newer multiplayer shooters

All in all, PUBG had a great run. It defined a genre, gave us countless memories, and shaped multiplayer gaming for years. But it‚Äôs time has clearly passed ‚Äî and that‚Äôs okay. RIP to one of the originals. It was good while it lasted.

review:
It's the Battle Royale that started the craze we didn't know we wanted. Overtime it has a smaller player base sure, but it still fits the style I enjoy. The Devs make some weird choices but seem to correct them when the community speaks out. the still actively update and tweak balancing.

The key things from this Battle Royale:
-Realistic movement (as in not a grapple hook and double jump 360 no scope or sliding for half a mile sprays with ridiculous accuracy because the game holds your hand.)
-Recoil is (realistic) as in you have to manually compensate and even then there are shot patterns that make it less like a laser and more like an actual M4 spray.
-A variety of maps, weapons, and blue zone circle spawns that keeps games fresh and different each playthrough.
- All of the paces... what I mean is you have slow catch your breath moments, plan your next move, gear up, and faster paced medium range fights, and really fast close range fights. You just have to figure out which you need in the moment and how to accomplish it. (sometimes you don't need the kill, you need a better position for the next round)
- Mechanics are solid, they take time to get used to because you're not a super human soldier grown in a lab. I'm not talking about bugs so much as the actual mechanics of the game. Often gunplay skill both long range and short range feels rewarding without too much flash or UI noise for a kill or knock.

Key issues with PUBG:
- If you're looking to be a superhuman or have a bunch of special power (that everyone has that picks that class or character) then you're probably not going to like this. It focuses more on positioning, firearms, skill, raw reaction and recoil compensation, sometimes you just get beat because you're in a tough spot, have the wrong gear, or just plain bad luck and there isn't a bunch of mechanics on a hotbar to save you.
- Vehicles for some reason feel way softer and weightless that in the past, always rolling or flipping of little things like the have bad weight ratio and no suspension and it didn't always feel like that. 
- The slow removal of choice. They removed .45cal as a caliber for SMGs, put the DBS shotgun back into crates. overall recent decisions have restricted player choices more than anything for combat preference and skill. SMG go MP5K, Assault go Beryl or M4, Sniping go M24/ or any bolty really, and the ONLY LMG the SAW. (MG is crate i'm talking about found weapons and the poor DP28...I haven't seen one in months, almost years and if i had i overlooked it easily because its garbage, fun, but garbage.)
-Cheaters are still a thing, as with most games, but PUBG is pretty soft on them (probably because of the smaller player base). I think hardware bans is what most of the community of any competitive franchise always want and I'm always confused by Companies that can't understand player retention goes up when the community is fair and strict. 
- In game rewards lean towards loot crates and battle passes for certain items but I do have to give them credit with the fact that a lot of new outfits, emotes, and other skins are purchasable directly through the shop. My main grief with this is progressive skins are loot crate orientated. (plus side is skins mean nothing for actual gameplay other than you are more colorful and easier to see most of the time.)

Conclusion:
I like the game, it's still fun years later and I bought it year one. Community is luckily pretty chill with rare instances of rage or foul talk and you can turn it off it annoys you. Cheaters are what the always are, people who can't actually play worth a dang and want to feel good ruining other people's time. Die quick to them so you can get a better round next match or kill them and laugh internally that you beat someone essentially on roids.
Final thought on the weapons and recent balancing.
In my opinion, instead of starting to put up guide rails so that players only end up using specific meta weapons; they need to expand their game arsenal, like when they added the ACE, Bery. that was heck of a lot of fun to test and play around with. Add more calibers and weapons. ( you already have 5.7mm in the game for the P90, branch our, make the FN 5.7 pistol 20 round mag and does good damage to armor. Switch up what people like about the game and lean in to it, the variety of weapons, calibers, and combat loads people carried made a team feel more versatile and unique i get you don't want to go overboard and create too much diversity which leads to a lot of waste...but you can continue to innovate.

Y'all have fun now you hear. 
If you see me don't shoot. I still will, I'm just asking you not to.

review:
Once again, the devs don't really care about the community. They keep adding updates that nobody asked for. Aimpunch, the DMR nerf, and tons of unimaginable things that aren't even enjoyable anymore.

Look, I want PUBG to rise again. It's a game that's simple but complex. But nerfing everything just because new players can't keep up is diabolically killing this game. Hundreds of hours of playing, ruined by one update.

If they want to create an easy way for new players to keep up, they should develop better matchmaking. For example, I played on another account that was only Lv. 1, and after just five matches, I was suddenly matched against Level 500, God-tier Master Rank players. How is that possible?

FPS games are difficult. I don't care if someone can't hold their recoil, if you can't, don't play an FPS in the first place. Everyone stayed with PUBG because it's rewarding and they enjoyed the complexity. If the devs really don't care about the community, then this is the downfall of a game that I truly enjoy :)

review:
My honest review: 3/10

Used to play this game very long time ago when it came out. Back in the day it was fun, but recently I decided to play it again. Played over 100 hours and was fully disappointed.

1. Game does everything to make you to spend more money on new skins, passes, badges etc. I understand that game is free and devs need money, but even with players spending money, devs do not give anything in return. Only thing they update is new skins.
2. Invisible walls. Even if you clearly see the enemy with your scope from the corners of wall, tree, car, etc., bullets still hit invisible objects.
3. Ranked mode that you paid money for - is not ranked at all. Beginner playing ranked ends up playing against the enemy with highest ranks. What is the point of naming something a "ranked" without actually adding raking mechanics? (Well.... answer is money)
4. Terrible driving mechanics. Really really bad! Car jumps and flips as if it weight 10kg. Car hits a very very small pit and slips over. This is absurd!!!

The reason I gave this game 3/10 is because I played with friends and we had fun hitting or shocking each other with stun gun, dying together in car crash and so on. Otherwise, I would have given 0.5/10

review:
I really enjoyed this game. Playing it feels like an incredibly tough challenge that I need to overcome to become better. I also liked the recent event with the zombie mode, which, unfortunately, was removed shortly after; it was fun to spend some time there. Even more amusing was that there were many players in that mode who were literally climbing walls and jumping on invisible textures. I didn‚Äôt even realize at first whether it was intended or against the rules.

One downside of this game is the lack of fair matchmaking. This means that in PUBG, you could be a level 1 player, but you‚Äôll be matched with level 500 players who have been playing longer than you‚Äôve been alive. In this game, nobody will spare you; you will likely be told that you are a bad player and insulted if you sit in a corner trying to learn the game. It‚Äôs hard to cope with negativity that arises literally from nothing, which ruins the atmosphere. Interestingly, you can do nothing to these players and just die, and they‚Äôll still call you a bad player and try to hurt you verbally. Fortunately, there‚Äôs a mute function for irritants.

As I mentioned at the beginning, I really liked this game because, forgetting about the negativity, even in a normal match, you can mess around with friends without any seriousness and throw frying pans at each other. I think that‚Äôs what keeps me here, as there‚Äôs positivity in that. This game truly has something more than just starting a match, shooting, and lobbies. It‚Äôs just pleasant for me. My overall rating of the game is 9/10.
name: PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS

review:
During these 7 years of playing PUBG, I never learned to play normally. I won very rarely, my friends helped me win, they killed over 10 players, and I did 0 and only did assists.

I fall from a plane, collect medicine, weapons, ammunition, there is a moment when there are no cars, I walk, a sniper kills me from afar or is hit by a car with enemies. There is also a time when you are exchanging fire with enemies or want to run to a safe zone - your internet connection is lost and you can't reconnect to the current server. From my point of view, this game is most intended for playing with friends, because if you join a squad with random players, no one will listen to you and they will land in another place and die after a short time or leave from the match. If you play in single player mode, there are many players who will be hiding in the bushes or in houses waiting for you with shotguns. There is also very professional players in single player mode, even if you are a beginner. 7-8/10

review:
PUBG ‚Äî Still One of the Best Battle Royales

Even after all these years, PUBG remains one of the most satisfying and intense battle royale experiences out there. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs come a long way since launch.

The Good:

Realistic gunplay that still feels unmatched compared to other shooters.

Tactical gameplay that rewards patience, strategy, and skill.

Huge variety of maps and weapons, keeping matches fresh.

Great updates and improvements over time, especially with performance and anti-cheat.

Still delivers that heart-pounding final circle adrenaline rush.


The Bad:

Occasional bugs and desync issues still pop up.

Newer players can struggle with the skill gap.

Some servers can feel inconsistent at times.


Final Verdict:
PUBG may not be the flashiest or most casual-friendly shooter, but it‚Äôs still the most grounded and rewarding battle royale for players who want real tension and realism.

Rating: 10.001/10 ‚Äî Classic gameplay that still holds strong in 2025.

review: This game ruined my life, I started out playing casually sometimes a couple times a day, then a couple times a week, a few times a year. I quit playing got a job and worked long hours. THIS GAME RUINED MY LIFE I GOT A JOB FOR THE FIRST TIME AT 38 YEARS OLD! Had I kept playing this game on the Mcdonalds' WiFi and a extension cord plugged into the Burger King outlet on the outside of the building I would had never gotten a job. Worse thing ever! I had to get up early, interact with people... I HAD TO DO THIS 5 TIMES A WEEK!.... Horrible experience!!!! Now I'm back to playing hidden in the back of a Kroger. I have unlimited food, drinks, WiFi and electricity. I sleep of the day and live like a King of the night 4 out of 5 stars... The bedding is noisy as it's cardboard and plastic wrap. PUBG 5 out of 5 stars!

review:
Very fun military battle royale  shooter. However, when I downloaded this game I didn't expect anime and "fortnite" collabs and now with skibidi coming around this game is sadly not the game I thought it was. Not to mention that 90% of my lobbies contain bots even though in lvl 160. I don't think I have played a single match of solo's without fighting a bot. This game is sadly not what it was from watching videos from the release

If I could I would give this game a 8/10 still, it's the bots and non military cosmetics that ruin it for me. Bots are so prevalent its hard not to give this game a down vote sadly, I just want to verse real people.

Also you can't play third person duos and you can't play solo ranked which is very strange

However the gunplay and strategy this game offers can't be ignored so I have to give this game an upvote

review:
6.5/10 
(Tl;dr)  The game is extremely fun, independently if you are playing with friends or alone, but can be considered slow and at times boring for players that aren¬¥t used to a more "realistic" Battle Royale. It doesn¬¥t require much skill, but there are many mechanics and resources to learn.

Pros: 
 - Great if you want a great mixture of FPS action and survival mechanics.
 - Good for playing both alone or with friends.
 - Quick to start a match (none of mine took more than 30s to start).
 - If you appreciate some level of realism when it comes to the guns, that can be a good option. It still far from real life, but way more closer than games like Valorant, Overwatch or Apex. 
 - It doesn¬¥t require much skill to play and have fun.

Cons
 - Since it has a more realistic tone compared to many Battle Royale and FPS/TPS games, it can be considered slow and at times, boring. 
 - Even though it doesn¬¥t require much skill, there are many mechanics, strategies and resources to learn that aren¬¥t explained (as far as I know, there aren¬¥t in-game tutorials for those).


Even though I don¬¥t have much playing time in this account, I have played it in other accounts and also on mobile, so I feel pretty confident that I have enough knowledge about this game to write a review.

review:
From Running Man with Arnold Schwarzenegger to CaptainSparklez‚Äôs Hunger Games Minecraft series, battle royale has always been my jam. There‚Äôs just something about throwing a bunch of people into a shrinking map and watching the madness unfold that never gets old.
PUBG nails that feeling. It‚Äôs raw, intense, and kind of brutal in the best way. You drop in with nothing, scramble for gear, and hope you don‚Äôt get sniped while looting a bathroom. Every match feels like a mini survival movie, and when you finally clutch that win? Pure dopamine.
It‚Äôs not the prettiest game out there, and yeah, sometimes the bugs or lag make you want to uninstall. But when it‚Äôs running smooth, it‚Äôs still one of the most satisfying shooters around. No flashy powers or gimmicks‚Äîjust you, your squad (hopefully not trolling), and the grind for that chicken dinner.
If you‚Äôre into tactical gameplay and don‚Äôt mind sweating a little, PUBG‚Äôs still got it.
name: PUBG: BATTLEGROUNDS

review: Game is rife with cheaters, when you have 100 players in a match you probably got 2 or 3 cheaters. I see cheaters team up in solo. How hard is it to catch two guys running next to each other without shooting the other for 15 minutes? Devs cant seem to see this or dont care. Also the only way not to get spotted by ESPers is to hide as low a possible in ditches or in houses. Unfortunately the devs blue wall mechanic is what the cheaters rely on to find you. Oh and the icing on the cake is being matched with a level 2 that pwns because they are a cheater and just created a new account after being banned for using too obvious of hacks. Devs really don't care to check stats or to even make new players play on their own away from veteran players... Easy fixes but MONEY is all that matters. review:
[b]TL;DR: Don't let the old 'Mixed' score fool you. The original, clunky, and utterly brutal grand-daddy of Battle Royale is now Free-to-Play, and its core, high-stakes gunplay remains a genre masterclass.[/b]

If you can endure the frustration of a steep learning curve and the occasional cheater, the sheer, heart-stopping adrenaline rush of a final circle in PUBG is still an experience you cannot find anywhere else. For the price of [b]$0.00[/b], this is an absolute must-try for any shooter fan.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Grand-Daddy of Battle Royale, Reborn[/h2]

PUBG is not *Apex*. It's not *Fortnite*. It‚Äôs a messy, high-friction, military sim-lite that thrives on its own imperfection. While the movement feels heavy and the animations are often janky, this deliberate clumsiness is precisely what makes every engagement a desperate, high-stakes fight for survival. This game forces you to respect the terrain, the sound, and the recoil in a way no other BR does.

The gunplay is, quite simply, [b]unmatched[/b]. Master the recoil patterns, calculate your bullet drop, and landing that long-distance headshot with an 8x-scoped Kar98k feels more rewarding than any kill streak in a faster-paced shooter. Every piece of loot has a meaningful impact, transforming your initially unarmed avatar into a walking arsenal. The decision to go Free-to-Play has made the player base explode again, meaning matches are fast, full, and the action is always close by‚Äîeven if the map is massive.

[h2]The Consumer Advocate's Caution[/h2]

Now for the inevitable caveats. The overall "Mixed" score is largely due to the game's notorious, decade-long struggle with performance and cheaters. While optimization has significantly improved in recent patches, server desync and ping differences can still ruin a gunfight. More importantly, the [u]cheater problem is persistent[/u]. KRAFTON releases weekly ban notices, but you will still inevitably be eliminated by a suspiciously accurate long-range spray. It is the cost of doing business in a high-profile, free-to-play BR, and it remains the single biggest deterrent to a perfect score.

The monetization is aggressive, focusing entirely on cosmetics, Season Passes, and the occasional exclusive currency for specific weapon skins. Thankfully, none of the purchases impact gameplay, keeping the core experience entirely fair. However, be prepared for pop-ups and a dizzying number of cosmetic options if you start poking around the menus.

[h2]Pros & Cons: The Final Scorecard[/h2]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] Unmatched, world-class gunplay that rewards high-skill and patience.
[*] Free-to-Play model provides unlimited entertainment value.
[*] Core tension and adrenaline rush of the final circle is unrivaled in the genre.
[*] Massive map diversity (Erangel, Miramar, Taego) forces constant strategy shifts.
[*] Playing with a squad provides peak cooperative chaos and rewarding teamwork.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] Persistent problem with cheaters and poor matchmaking at high skill levels.
[*] Movement feels notably clunky and stiff compared to modern competitors.
[*] Extremely steep learning curve and punishing difficulty for new players.
[*] Aggressive cosmetic monetization that can clutter the UI.
[/list]

[h2]Conclusion: The Chicken Dinner is Worth the Price[/h2]

This is the Battle Royale experience distilled to its purest, most punishing form. It is a slow burn that ignites into a blinding flash of gunfire and adrenaline. Yes, you will get killed by a hacker you never saw. Yes, you will crash your Dacia into a fence post. But when you manage to outplay the final squad, loot the last body, and hear that glorious "WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER" sound, every moment of frustration melts away.

It's free. Jump in. The value proposition is too high to ignore.

review:
‚ÄúPay to Cheat‚Äù
I keep coming back to PUBG hoping things have changed ‚Äî but nope, same story every time. The game has become pay-to-cheat, and the hackers are everywhere.
The devs ban usernames, sure, but that‚Äôs like trying to fix a leaky boat with duct tape ‚Äî they‚Äôre back in a few minutes with a new account and the same cheats. It‚Äôs honestly impressive how consistent the problem has stayed.
PUBG used to be about skill, survival, and those heart-pounding final circles. Now it‚Äôs just frustration and wallhacks.
Anyway, BF6 is around the corner, so I‚Äôm done wasting time here. Hopefully battlefield still rewards skill instead of scripts.

review:
[b]PUBG ‚Äî Where Danger is Hot and the Drop is Spicy üíã[/b]

Darling, if you like your survival games with a side of chaos and a dash of drama, [i]PUBG[/i] is ready to sweep you off your feet ‚Äî or snipe you from 300 meters. üíÖ

[u]üíÑ The Thrill of the Drop:[/u]
[list]
[*]Parachuting into Erangel or Miramar feels like choosing your fate ‚Äî will it be loot, love, or a lobby exit?
[*]Every match is a blind date with destiny. Sometimes you get a dinner, sometimes you get a frying pan to the face.
[*]Looting is foreplay. The real action starts when the circle shrinks and the tension rises.
[/list]

[u]üî´ Combat That Flirts With Your Sanity:[/u]
[list]
[*]Guns feel punchy, recoil is spicy, and headshots are pure satisfaction.
[*]Third-person peeking? Naughty. First-person duels? Intimate.
[*]Vehicles add drama ‚Äî nothing says ‚Äúromantic getaway‚Äù like a flaming buggy flipping through the air.
[/list]

[u]üë† Fashion & Flair:[/u]
[list]
[*]Dress to impress or undress to intimidate ‚Äî your wardrobe is your weapon.
[*]From tactical chic to beachwear assassin, you‚Äôll slay in every sense.
[*]Emotes let you flirt, flex, or taunt your way to victory.
[/list]

[u]üíã Squad Goals & Solo Fantasies:[/u]
[list]
[*]Play solo if you‚Äôre a lone wolf with a thirst for chaos.
[*]Duo for that spicy tension and whispered callouts.
[*]Squad for full-blown drama, betrayal, and clutch revives that feel like love confessions.
[/list]

[b]Final Seduction:[/b]  
[i]PUBG[/i] is messy, moody, and magnificently addictive. It‚Äôs not always fair, it‚Äôs not always kind ‚Äî but it‚Äôs always thrilling. Whether you're crawling through grass or crashing through windows, every moment is a tease, every kill a kiss.

[spoiler]Winner Winner... you know the rest, darling üòò[/spoiler]

review:
The Technical Graveyard: A Review of PUBG: Battlegrounds PC
Title: PUBG: Battlegrounds PC: Eight Years of Technical Debt Overshadowing the Core Experience

Verdict: The soul of the best-in-class Battle Royale gunplay is still here, but it's buried under frustrating server instability, persistent optimization problems, and a frustrating lack of fundamental technical overhaul.

Graphics & Optimization: The Legacy of Low Fidelity
The complaint of "poor graphics" isn't strictly about visual quality‚Äîmany older games still look great‚Äîit's about the technical debt inherited from the game's early access days. While Krafton has made visual tweaks over the years, the performance remains notoriously inconsistent.

For a game nearing its seventh anniversary since full release, PUBG is inexcusably difficult to run smoothly. Players with high-end modern hardware are still forced to dive into Reddit threads and external guides to tweak obscure settings, turn off graphical features, and sometimes even use third-party software just to achieve a stable framerate and eliminate the stuttering that cripples close-quarters combat. The visual fidelity itself often feels dated and muddy, failing to match the performance demands it places on a system. It's a game that performs like a next-gen title while looking like one from the last generation.

Bad Servers: Desync and Lag on the Last Circle
The server performance remains a severe, game-breaking problem that compromises the core gameplay loop. Too often, the high-stakes final circles are decided not by skill, but by desync and connection hiccups.

Shots that clearly connect fail to register, players die behind cover they reached seconds ago, and the overall netcode frequently feels sluggish, leading to frustrating and often confusing deaths. While general connectivity might be acceptable for looting, the moment you enter a high-tension gunfight, the lack of server stability turns precise gameplay into a coin flip. The experience is often defined by frustration rather than fair competition, making the skill ceiling feel arbitrary at times.

The Illusion of Upgradation
The claim that the game has had "no upgradation in 8 years" is a feeling, not a fact. The developers release new maps, new skins, new vehicles, and new seasonal passes constantly. However, these constant additions often feel like superficial dressing around a decaying core.

Where are the fundamental upgrades?

Movement: Despite minor quality-of-life additions, the character movement remains heavy, clunky, and often unresponsive compared to modern competitors.

Cheating: While the developers constantly issue ban reports, the fundamental anti-cheat measures feel inadequate. Rampant cheating, especially in higher ranks and certain regions, continues to plague the ecosystem, severely damaging player trust and making the experience feel fundamentally unbalanced.

Technical Foundation: New maps are added, but the underlying engine optimization that causes stuttering and poor performance persists.

The focus on continuous content churn (new skins and collaborations) over aggressively tackling the technical foundation and cheating problem suggests a priority of revenue generation over player experience. For a game that pioneered the genre, it‚Äôs a tragedy that its aging technology remains the primary barrier to recommending it to new players.

The core tactical challenge of PUBG is still unmatched, but until Krafton commits to a true, ground-up technical overhaul‚Äîaddressing the optimization, the cheating problem, and the server stability‚Äîit will remain a fascinating but deeply flawed relic of the Battle Royale genre.

review:
During a normal match with friends, we made it to the final phase when my character suddenly teleported across the map and fell from the sky out of nowhere. Seconds later, I was kicked and banned.

I didn‚Äôt cheat. What I assume happened, is that I was targeted by a hacker who manipulated my character to make it look like I was using exploits. It‚Äôs a known tactic: hackers do this to tilt matches in their favor by getting others banned. Instead of detecting the hacker, PUBG‚Äôs anti-cheat system flagged me, the victim. Either that or it was a bug, which would make it even more ridiculous.

When I contacted support, they didn‚Äôt even look into it. I got the same copy-pasted response multiple times claiming ‚Äúevery ban is thoroughly investigated,‚Äù which is clearly false. If anyone had actually reviewed the match data, it would‚Äôve been obvious to them that I was innocent. And now I'm sitting here with a 3-day ban for "unusual gameplay patterns".

I'm being punished for something entirely outside of my control, and the company is doing nothing to fix it, they even make it worse. Their so-called support doesn‚Äôt investigate, doesn‚Äôt care, and hides behind automated responses.

If a hacker targets you, you‚Äôll be banned instead of them and support will treat you like you‚Äôre disposable. Way to treat your  players.

review:
If you‚Äôre new, don‚Äôt play. I‚Äôm not just warning you I‚Äôm pleading with you for your own peace of mind and safety. Save yourself from all of this nonsense. It‚Äôs the most frustrating, unfair, and poorly managed game I‚Äôve ever played. The developers care more about money than their community if you don‚Äôt spend, you get nothing meaningful, just useless cosmetic junk and costumes pushing demonic agendas that have nothing to do with a war game.

it‚Äôs worth trusting those of us who have played and now rebuke this game for all the emptiness it gives us. I want to save the time of every single new player from this consuming, soulless garbage. I can‚Äôt use words strong enough to express how much you should run from it. Believe us when we say this is not worth your time, money, or energy.

If you have great aim and skill and want to jump into a game that makes you feel like the worst player of all time, go ahead. But if you don‚Äôt have the experience to support it, you won‚Äôt match the one that are chain to this game wasting their lives here I‚Äôm not even talking about the hackers, that‚Äôs just normal. And if you actually love pain, frustration, and despair, guess what it's still not worth it.

There are so many other games far more better than this one and it doesn't take much to beat it. If you don‚Äôt trust those who warn you, be ready for misery, regret, and a toxic experience. Do yourself a favor instead of slapping you in the face for another bad choice in your life and delete this game from your mind. Don‚Äôt even give it a chance.

review:
PUBG‚Ä¶ honestly, I have no idea how this game is still alive. The graphics look like something from 2013, yet it somehow needs a super powerful PC just to run without lag ‚Äî and even then, it still looks awful.

The performance? Trash. The servers? Laggy. The gameplay? Boring, buggy, and outdated. Every match feels like a struggle ‚Äî not because it‚Äôs challenging, but because the game itself is broken.

It‚Äôs supposed to be ‚Äúrealistic,‚Äù but all it gives you is clunky movement, horrible hit detection, and graphics that look like mud smeared on the screen.

And don‚Äôt even get me started on optimization ‚Äî the game runs worse than most modern titles with triple the quality. Apex Legends, Fortnite, Warzone ‚Äî literally any other battle royale does everything PUBG tries to do, but better in every possible way.

PUBG is the definition of wasted potential. A game that could‚Äôve been legendary but instead became a laggy, broken, outdated mess. Easily one of the worst battle royale experiences ever made.

review:
Good game but I cant play it anymore. I would love to try or re-live the others too but rocktstar ruined the whole experience with the steam-link that only they can remove. I went down a rabit hole reading about this problem online. At least hundreds but more then likely thousands of players who have paid their money via steam for the games needing the Rockstar laucher cant play it because Rockstar like to be in control of linking and unlinking steam accounts. 

For example: You didnt play a rockstar game you bought years ago for a while now and you forgot the login or mail to rockstar launcher. Congratiulations! All your Rockstar games on your steam account are worthless now! Even the ones you buy after it. Can you unlink? Yes you can, but they ask the most ridiculous information which almost nobody has laying around anymore. Who does remember the exact moment and date the laucher was linked to the steam account...?  They ask a lot. People who can actually collect the information that is asked to unlink a steam profile often have to wait weeks or months to get a final reaction from Rockstar. I sended a mail 3 times and only got a response once after about 5 weeks. 

So if you buy a Rockstar game and find yourself in this situation with not being able to link an new rockstar launcher account to your existing steamaccount, just return the game. 

For those who are still brave enough and want Rockstar to unlink, you can get a support ticket for this on their website. Steam cant do anything about this, its all a rockstar problem. You could also keep making steam accounts to link to new launchers and keep buying the same games again and again. It seems like Rockstar want you to do that xD

review: hello everyone i know i'm late to be writing a review with how close we are to getting gta 6 but i just wanna say It‚Äôs hard to believe that after all these years, we‚Äôre finally getting ready to say goodbye to GTA V. For so long, it wasn‚Äôt just a game ‚Äî it was a place we kept coming back to. The streets of Los Santos, the chaos of Heists gone wrong, the late-night drives down Vespucci Beach with the radio on ‚Äî they all became familiar, almost comforting. We made memories there, whether it was pulling off impossible stunts, getting chased by cops for hours, or just standing on a mountain watching the sun go down. But with GTA VI on the horizon, it feels like the end of an era. As exciting as the future looks, part of us will always miss the world we‚Äôve spent more than a decade in ‚Äî that crazy, beautiful masterpiece that was Grand Theft Auto V.

review:
The Best GTA Ever Made

There‚Äôs not much to say ‚Äî it‚Äôs GTA. For me, this is the best game in the entire franchise. The story mode is simply amazing ‚Äî no complaints at all. Both the story itself and the three main characters are incredibly well done.

The online mode is even better, thanks to the massive amount of content the game offers. You can play solo and still have fun, but it‚Äôs 10x better with friends, since there‚Äôs so much more you can do together.

You can easily spend hours and hours without even noticing, and the fact that the game still receives updates from time to time keeps it fresh with new content.

review:
Yo, I just tore through Grand Theft Auto V again on the Enhanced Edition, and it's like a decade-old fever dream where three dysfunctional dads turn Los Santos into their personal demolition derby‚Äîpure, unfiltered chaos!  Swapping between Michael midlife-crisis golfing, Franklin boosting rides like a pro, and Trevor snorting lines off a chainsaw had me cackling through heists that go wrong in the funniest ways‚Äîgold masks everywhere, helicopters exploding mid-air. Story's a satirical gut-punch on American excess, but the open-world freedom? Steal a jet, grief NPCs off mountains, or just cruise beaches blasting radio bangers.
GTA Online's still bumping in 2025 with 40k-90k Steam players grinding heists and yacht parties‚Äîmods turn it into Shrek Simulator or flying elephants for troll lobbies that leave me wheezing.  Los Santos looks ray-traced gorgeous now, but cops still spawn out of thin air to ruin your vibe. 9.5/10. Timeless mayhem‚ÄîGTA 6 who? Grab the crew and cause havoc!
name: Grand Theft Auto V Legacy

review:
LIke everyone else, I grew up playing Grand Theft Auto.

I do love them but I lost access to my old email that was unfortunately used for my Rockstar Games account and now I cannot boot this or any other Rockstar game using their 3rd party launcher (Red Dead, GTA IV, likely GTA VI).

Rockstar support seems to be a team of bots, sending me the exact same copy-pasted message with a different agent in the signature. Despite attaching proof, they just automatically close my ticket and I cannot reply, saying "We investigated" and now I can't access games I've spent hundreds of dollars on, and saves I've spend hundreds of hours on. They can't just unlink my Steam account from my Rockstar Games account, instead I can never play something made by them again as long as it uses their 3rd party launcher.

If the actions of this company past and present have proven one thing its that they just want you to buy their game as many times as possible.

review:
Honestly, Grand Theft Auto V: Legacy feels like the game we all loved, but finally running the way it was meant to. The visuals are cleaner, performance is smoother, and the city feels more alive than ever. Driving, shooting, and just messing around in Los Santos still hit hard after all these years.

It‚Äôs not a brand-new experience, but it‚Äôs the best version of a classic ‚Äî a proper tribute to a game that defined a whole generation.

9/10 ‚Äì Still unmatched after all this time.

review:
This game fascinated me even before I truly understood the concept of gaming. After 11 years, I finally got the chance to play it ‚Äî and it absolutely lived up to the hype. GTA V has become, and will always be, one of my favorite games of all time.

I‚Äôve spent over 100+ hours on the Enhanced Version, which is great in its own right, but the Legacy Version has a unique vibe that the newer one can never quite replicate.

The Story Mode is simply goated ‚Äî
 I often find myself doing random stuff just to chill and relax. On the other hand, GTA Online feels like an endless grind with too much content to keep up with.

If I had to choose, Story Mode easily beats GTA Online for me.

Overall:
‚≠ê An absolute banger ‚Äî worth every bit of money and every hour spent playing.
name: Grand Theft Auto V Legacy

review:
[h1]Great GTA[/h1]

[h3]Story[/h3]
You play 3 characters in virtual Los Angeles. You'll commit several crimes and solve problems, that arise for such a lifestyle. Good story, nice Eastereggs. Classic cultural commentary included. The story is fun, generally up-beat and a bit superficial. More like GTA San Andreas than GTA IV.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Great open world. Arcade driving. Best shooting out of all GTA games.

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
Absolutely fine.

[h3]Achievements[/h3]
Achievements are mostly fun to strive for and guide you through the game. Story, collectibles and multiplayer. 100% completion includes some annoying multiplayer achievements and you'll have to connect a YouTube-channel for one achievement.
name: Grand Theft Auto V Legacy

review:
I Aint Installing Some Spyware (BattlEye) Just To Play GTA Online!!!

After thousands of hours in Los Santos, I should feel rewarded, not punished. But the latest BattlEye anti-cheat update in GTA Online feels less like protection and more like betrayal.

Rockstar promised a cleaner, fairer GTA Online experience with kernel-level BattlEye integration, claiming it would finally curb the endless wave of modders and griefers. In reality? Modders still roam free, while honest players are forced to install invasive, kernel-level software that digs deep into our systems and offers little in return.

The result: no meaningful improvement, just another layer of inconvenience for the very community that‚Äôs kept this decade-old game alive.

BattlEye: Security or Surveillance?

Now we‚Äôre asked to trust Rockstar with kernel-level access to our PCs ‚Äî the same Rockstar that can‚Äôt balance mission payouts or prevent cheaters from raining cash in public lobbies. BattlEye was supposed to stop the madness, yet modders still teleport, crash sessions, and ruin lobbies daily. The only difference is that now legitimate players are the ones facing crashes, false positives, and privacy concerns.

It feels like a cruel joke: the cheaters are fine, and the loyal players are the ones under surveillance.

A Veteran‚Äôs Verdict

After thousands of hours of gameplay, I can say this with conviction: GTA Online has lost its soul. What was once chaos in a fun way has turned into corporate monotony disguised as gameplay. The grind is endless, the missions are lifeless, the prices are absurd ‚Äî and now the anti-cheat punishes the wrong people.

BattlEye was meant to fix GTA Online. Instead, it just exposed how far Rockstar has drifted from the players who built this world in the first place.

Problem About The Game:
The Economy Designed to Exhaust You

Earning money in GTA Online has become a grind that borders on parody. Every activity feels like a chore ‚Äî the same tired missions recycled for the hundredth time, paying next to nothing for hours of work. Even the cheapest vehicles are priced like luxury sports cars.

When a rust-bucket sedan costs millions, you know the economy is broken. It‚Äôs a system designed to frustrate players into opening their wallets. The game‚Äôs grind is no longer about progress; it‚Äôs about testing how much tedium you can endure before you give up and buy Shark Cards.
name: Grand Theft Auto V Legacy

review:
The game is just a masterpiece, as is most Rockstar games are tbf. Just finished my second playthrough of the story and damn is it just as good as years ago when I played it on console. The characters, heists, side missions, all of it is wrapped up in a beautiful package for you to enjoy. Even the graphics in this 'legacy' version are honestly not even that far behind today's standards at all. 

All in all still a great game after all of these years, just makes you wonder how insane GTA 6 will be whenever that gets released...

review:
after 160 hours i can say gta v is still one of the best games ever made
the story mode aged really well and the characters are still some of the best in any game
franklin, michael and trevor are all great in their own ways and the missions are super fun even after replaying them a few times

gta online is a whole different thing
sometimes its chaos, sometimes its just you driving around listening to music and vibing
ive met cool people there and also got blown up by random kids with flying bikes every 5 minutes
still fun tho

the amount of stuff you can do is insane
races, missions, heists, drifting, roleplay servers, or just messing around in free roam
there‚Äôs always something to do even after hundreds of hours
